name: t1_c8vuv93
author: bold_arrow_of_time
body:
Yeah, you are definitely right. They do look remarkably similar. I think John does look fairly unusual for an Englishman as he does have a quite flat nose and narrow eyes. 

While it looks like some of the pictures in your links may be from his retirement period (most notably the one where he is naked and cradling up to Yoko), a majority of them are between 1968 and I'd say around '74 as that is when the pair of them were most active, both in music and activism. Mind you, John did re-enter the music business shortly before his death in 1980 so there are a few shots in there that can throw you off. You can usually tell though because they have both aged significantly, as can be seen in [this shot](http://i.imgur.com/P6ltXc8.jpg).

Cheers for my first delta, glad I could help shed some light on it.

name: t1_c9cwx8n
author: NeroJack

name: t1_c9d5s0t
author: Sandlicker
body:
Depression as a mood and depression as a mood disorder are two different things. Many people experience periods of transient depression. This is not a disorder, but it still can be quite severe and result in self-harm or suicide. Depression as a mood disorder is persistent, and in many cases lifelong, feelings of being "down", inadequate, worthless, suicidal, and just generally dissatisfied with life. 
These may be people who are experiencing transient periods of depression, these may be liars, or they may be people covering up their depression. Speaking for myself as someone who has an anxiety disorder that causes persistent depression, I was known to be quite a boisterous, friendly and upbeat person in college. Many times I was the life of a party and I had a very large group of friends among whom I was known for being excitable and happy. Then I would go to my dorm room and cry or cut myself. Neither of those things was fake either. My friends genuinely made me happy, and why would I want to bring out my depression into a situation in which I was happy? Why would I want to deliberately bring myself and others down? On top of this, I would occasionally experience manic episodes. Mania is the other pole from which bipolar disorder gets its name. Whereas depression is characterized by a lack of energy and feelings of apathy or hopelessness, mania is characterized by an overwhelming intensity of energy that can result in anxiousness and panic, often resulting in that hair-trigger anger that people imagine when they think of BPD, or if you're lucky and spending time with people you like that mania can result in a high-energy euphoria that is actually one of the best feelings I have ever experienced. One of the things that bummed me out the most when I went on medication was knowing that these euphoric episodes would go away.

Anyways, hope that helped some.

name: t1_c9v8fs2
author: cfaris
body: I don't believe I ever said that threats of suicide shouldn't be taken seriously. I agree with the opposite. Even if it is a call for help, any normal person would feel an obligation to take action. I had a friend in high school who, before I met him, "attempted" commit suicide by over dosing. In the back of my mind I always wondered why he chose such an unreliable method. Of course I never said that to him out of common  decency but I was illegitimately curious for the reasons behind it. I feel like a struck a bit of a nerve with some people here but that was a natural side affect of curiosity.

name: t1_cb3javy
author: Serang
body:
No he would not have and here are the reasons why:

1.  Location of the body

Trevyon had been on the phone with his girlfriend all the way up until the time of the attack. Treyvon was intending to visit his mom's fiancee's house and according to his girlfriend, had reached his destination.  

The girlfriend then claims that here is where Zimmerman attacked while Zimmerman claims that Treyvon doubled back and went chasing after Zimmerman.

Now, the body was found a good 100 ft or so away from Treyvon's mom's fiancee's house in the direction of Zimmerman's car.

This means that if Treyvon had reached his mom's fiancee's house, he wouldve had to double back and chase after Zimmerman to instigate the fight at the location where the body was found.

The location of the body is consistent with Zimmerman's story and is a very likely indicator that Treyvon started the attack.

This fact alone can acquit Zimmerman by simply claiming self defense.

name: t1_cb3jjs2
author: [deleted]
body:
This a misinformed exaggeration. You think the families of black people don't seek justice? You don't think ANY black people snitch? Your view of black people sounds like it was made by watching crime dramas.  You don't think there are marches and protests when gang violence claims black teenagers lives? The only reason you know about the Trayvon ones is because it extends beyond the black community, which you are clearly not a part of.
So you don't believe in self defense? Interesting. A dude is following you around. You don't know why. Maybe he's trying to rob you. Maybe he's trying to hurt you. How was Trayvon supposed to know this guy following him wasn't going to jack him up and steal his wallet? Just because he's not black? Zimmerman was invading Trayvon's space and profiling him and following him around. I'd be really sketched out and concerned if that was happening to me.

You have no way of knowing Trayvon put his hands on Zimmerman "because he thought he deserved a beat down." That phrasing also postures it as if Trayvon were following Zimmerman around, which was not the case.

I agree this case has been twisted and the media should keep their nose out of this and all cases in my opinion. However, you clearly do not understand why this is important to people of color.

name: t1_cb3qcwp
author: novagenesis
body:
Because the claim that Martin acting in self defense (as an attempt to prevent a claim that Zimmerman acted in self-defense) makes no sense when you acknowledge that the "terrified" Martin chose not to escape the situation when given more than enough time.  If I thought I was being chased by someone who might hurt me, I'd be behind a locked door and calling the cops in under a minute.

Zimmerman did not, at the time, think that Martin was attacking him.  He thought he found the burglar, whose reactions, including the first flight, fit the expected profile of a criminal caught red handed.  Assuming Zimmeran's story was true (we just don't know), that makes Martin the one who initiated the physical conflict that led to Zimmerman fearing for his life and shooting Martin.

From common sense and forensics point of view, there are more unknowns that work in Zimmerman's favor than Martin's.  Martin is terrified and running away, but chooses not to move to safety.  Why?

Zimmerman somehow ended up on his back with a wounded head before shooting Martin (who was directly on top of him).  How?

Even their attitudes.  Zimmerman was don't-let-him-escape angry, while Martin seemed "do anything to survive" scared... It would be flip-a-coin over who started it, except that Martin seems to have chosen fight over flight in those 4 minutes when Zimmerman hadn't even gotten that far.

name: t1_cf6qwoo
author: eye_patch_willy
body:
Fully endorsing /u/electricfistula's great answer, and adding on.  Season 8 never felt like a final season.  So many new characters were introduced, just to be killed off.  Dr. Vogel's character, while brilliantly played by Charlotte Rampling, made no fucking sense.  Her connection to Dexter and Harry is ludicrous.  At no point in the series was she even hinted at.  To me, it was clear that the writers never envisioned this aspect of Dexter's myth when they created the show and the character, it was purely forced into place for this one season.  
  
The other new characters also seemed to only be introduced to be killed so that the characters we've all come to know get to live (save Deb, who dies because of a one in a million blood clot- just so she and Dex can have one last conversation while she's in the hospital).  No other arc is closed.  Angel, Quinn, and Matthews are still in the dark about who Dexter really was.  This makes LaGuerta's death even more pointless than it already seemed.  Jamie still hasn't done anything important.  
  
Those things plus Dexter and Hannah turning into bumbling idiots as already pointed out turned the last season into a disaster.  The other HUGE GAPPING hole that was never addressed in either S7 or S8 was the scene in S5 where Deb walks in on Dexter and Lumen about to kill Jordan Chase (they can't see each other because of a opaque tarp) and Deb lets them go.  Suddenly Deb finds out Dexter is a serial killer and has this huge crisis of conscious.  In what universe does it make sense that the scene in the basement never comes up between the two of them???????????????

name: t1_cggd8lf
author: learhpa
body:
Sure. Of course it's a political stunt that will have no immediate effect.

But if enough states do this, it creates pressure on their representatives in the federal legislature to do the same thing. Successful passage at the state level helps create the political conditions for successful passage at the federal level.

And that's where it gets interesting.

name: t1_ch338wb
author: [deleted]
body:
I say that someone is responsible/to blame if that person directly and consciously causing an action to occur.  If you have a different definition, tell me, but this is the one I like to use.  Him drinking did not make her rape him.  He didn't trigger a rape instinct in her that made her lose control of her actions.  Him drinking did not affect her at all, so she had no reason to commit a crime against him.  Therefore, he is not responsible.  It's a good idea not to get black out drunk, but that makes him thoughtless, not responsible.

Nothing illegal should happen to you if you haven't done anything illegal (I mean this like being in prison would be illegal if it wasn't ordered by the government.)

name: t1_ch3p1te
author: Mavericgamer
body:
There is a line between "drunk" and blackout, not conscious drunk. When you are so drunk that you can't stand, don't remember the next morning, and aren't even conscious half the time, active sex can't happen. If one party is that drunk, and sex still happened, it implies the other party was not.

In the situation you mentioned, you might be too drunk to safely operate a motor vehicle, but not too drunk to consent. If both parties were equally drunk, however, then they were both equally able to consent.

name: t1_cj1jfd0
author: AccountHaver25
body:
The thing about that statement is that you need only one person out of 7 billion to find people with moderate to severe acne attractive for your view to be false.

If you mean most people don't find people with moderate to severe acne attractive well that's subjective. Attractiveness varies according to region, culture and personal preference.

If you mean you don't find people with moderate to severe acne attractive, well that isn't really /r/ChangeMyView territory. Personal preference is hard to change.

name: t1_cj1lhpg
author: Prof_Acorn
body:
Skin complexion doesn't affect attractiveness as much as bone structure. Take the most attractive celebrity you can find and photoshop a few pimples on their face. Now compare that to someone with beady eyes, a long rectangle face, a hard protruding brow line, a gummy smile, and a double chin.

Poor complexion might not be as attractive as perfect complexion, but it doesn't play a role in attraction as much as bone structure and a healthy weight.

name: t1_cky7neb
author: TehRedBaron
body: That's not how heroin tolerance works. Tolerance increases dramatically over the course of an addiction. It's not just that a seasoned heroin addict can *tolerate* a dose that would kill most people, it's that they can easily get to the point where a "normally fatal dose" is not even enough for them to *feel.*

body: I think we have more common ground than we thought. Essentially, yes, cops are town guards with itchy trigger fingers. I don't think we'll ever see them trained to any standard of competence. We have to stop worrying about cops and start talking about giving citizens the rights to defend themselves. At least when citizens defend themselves they are held liable to the full extent of the law. In this way, we can create a culture where it is understood that assaulting someone has deep consequences but that defending your life also has some restrictions.

name: t1_cpwaiv3
author: jrafferty
body:
Define recover. 

If it weren't for the sedative and pain killer I could have driven myself home from the procedure if I had to (they would never allow this lol). The drugs kept me comfortable that 1st night and those were all they gave me. The next day it felt like my eyes had a sunburn and had some grit in them. Kinda sore and irritated but nothing overly harsh (I'd peg it at a 5 or 6 on a scale to 10).  I was fully functional and had clear vision. The pain went away little by little every day and I think I was back at work 72 hours after the surgery IIRC.

name: t1_cs8wghl
author: skunkardump
body:
I would say that Fedor was GOAT heavyweight in any promotion based on his legendary win streak, something I doubt anyone will ever come close to in UFC.  However I do think that not having to cut weight is something of an advantage at heavyweight.  Whether or not it's more of an advantage than size itself is debatable, but clearly most heavyweights don't bulk up to 265, and there are very few human beings that would have to cut down to 265 (unless they're fat obviously).  There seems to be diminishing returns on size once you get well over 200 lbs.  Ali wasn't that big himself, though he had a huge reach, much like Jon Jones, who many would have considered a favorite at heavyweight, even against the likes of Cain Velasquez.  It's extremely rare for fighters in other divisions to weigh in at less than a pound or two under the limit.  If UFC had a super heavyweight division I probably wouldn't give Lesnar as much credit.

Cain also has more losses in title fights, and what he may or may not do in the future is irrelevant.  Couture has more wins in title fights than Cain, especially if you consider his lhc reigns.  Would you consider Couture above Cain?

body:
He starts safe place in an attempt to open a dialogue with the inmates about their feelings ,and has helped at least Pennsatucky with her rage. Sam also actively researches psychology in an attempt to be better at his job.  
He may have inappropriate feelings for Red, but has he acted on them? Well a little, but more as a suggestion for when she gets out. He hasn't attempted to be with her sexually, which is a lot more than a good chunk of the other guards can say.  
Healy may be bigoted and racist, but not outwardly to the inmates themselves. I think he does care about his job and the girls, and his attitude reflects more of a problem with many white american men, but not as a counsellor.

name: t1_cstu94m
author: jfpbookworm
body:
[Done to death](http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMostDangerousVideoGame), pun intended.  In addition to anime, there's things like Tad Williams' *Otherland* series and, *Fate/Extra* and, of course, *The Matrix*.
I'm not clear on how SAO's premise is different.  You say that there's less focus on horror (meaning violent death?) or on gaming aspects, but that's the case for many of the other stories that use this idea.  What you're left with is "people from contemporary Earth are transported to a sword-and-sorcery world", which is [even more cliche](http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrappedInAnotherWorld).

name: t1_cthvpeo
author: eltappo
body: The other point would be that whilst cricket may not be the most competitive game for women soccer would have one of the highest participation sports for women, and she managed to be a part of a world top 10 team while focusing on a vastly different sport

name: t1_cti7mh5
author: MordorsFinest
body:
Bear in mind the Saiyans were a young species. In King Vegeta's lifetime they went from cavemen to a spacefaring race of conquerors. Before that they only had each other to fight, by King Vegeta's midlife the two most powerful Saiyans: Broly and Goku were already infants and the Saiyans were becoming stronger as a species by fighting everything in the universe. 

If Frieza didn't destroy them and Broly, for one, probably at even 5 or 6 years old  could have killed Frieza's henchmen and maybe Frieza himself. Frieza had excellent timing, if he waited even one decade Broly could have destroyed him and presumably Goku could have too.

One more decade? Goku and Vegeta killed Buu who was several times more powerful than Frieza. Give them an army of 100 Saiyans all presumably capable of going Super Saiyan...hell even the halfbreeds had no trouble! 

Frieza and his henchmen were more powerful than the Saiyans on the eve that they destroyed planet Vegeta, but the timing was perfect, Frieza was right to believe that the Saiyans could have become more powerful than him in a very short time.

name: t1_ctiqgmx
author: MordorsFinest
body:
He was weak because he hit his head and was raised by humans. If he wasnt he would have been violent.

Also Broly as an infant had that crazy power. And while King Vegeta did have him killed before trying to take on Frieza there's a chance that he would have unleashed Broly on Frieza first. Assuming Frieza felt like killing the Saiyans.

name: t1_ctisowf
author: mikestp
body: Jack Brabham is the only person to ever win a Formula One world championship driving a car built himself. We will have athletes in the future superior to what we've had in the past for any sport discipline but Jacks achievement will almost certainly never be repeated.

name: t1_ctlv7xc
author: Gunderik
body:
&Delta; While I'm not *entirely* convinced, I will say I'm more open about the ruling in the case should be. I could see it going either way now. The franchise's response *would* try to address everything with an excuse, whether anyone were guilty or not, but most of it seems perfectly reasonable. The main thing I have a problem with was this:
While it could be just a coincidence that looks really bad, I'm not buying that he was told he'd have to do his job and in response requested bribes of cash and shoes as a joke.

Thanks for the link to the team's response, I'll have to read that.

name: t1_cu2w6p8
author: unk
body: True but Grandpa Joe did give up his money for the second candy bar (the first was a birthday gift and the third golden ticket bar was gutter money).  Joe was willing to give up probably the only thing in his life that he enjoyed - his tobacco - just so Charlie could have a few extra moments of hope of finding a golden ticket.  That is pretty altruistic.

name: t3_1c4do4
author: NeroJack
body:
I believe depression isn't a mental disorder. CMV

So, I don't believe depression is a mental disorder. I don't mean to be disrespectful, I just feel that way.

I've seen so many moments when someone used it as an excuse to get out of work, to gain sympathy, or for attention.

Back in Middle School to gain attention people would throw depression around and I think it wasn't depression, but just teenage hormones. I've seen people who claimed to have depression one day and the next seem totally fine.

I feel like so many people have used it as an excuse it has ruined my opinion probably. But even then I feel like depression isn't its own disorder.

So CMV?

name: t3_1cd5dm
author: TwasAConspiracy
body:
I genuinely believe the Connecticut school shooting was fake/fabricated. CMV.

IMPORTANT: I want to be wrong about this! I realize it's an absolutely terrible thing to fake, but through all of the research I've done, all signs point to government fabrication to sway the public's views about gun control. 

The only information I have to back up my claim are videos on youtube, and articles on the internet, as well as other incidents in the past that have allegedly been staged/performed by the governments of multiple nations. Here are links: 

Videos suggesting the shooting was a hoax:
-http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFo3x_UgQ80
- http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-mlszDIRZb0

It appears that this type of this has happened before, with 911, the England bus bombing, etc. Internet research. 

So to conclude, I really want to see what you guys think. I don't WANT it to be fake, but I think it was.

body:

Steve Harvey seems to have a solid head on his shoulders. He has become successful without (seemingly) selling out. It appears he still remembers where he came from and who has helped him along the way. And I think he may be one of the best family feud hosts since Richard Dawson. 

My friend... Hates my opinion with a passion and thinks Steve Harvey is of the devil.  Why?

Change my view
